ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Entirely new methods; experiential, speculative, and interdisciplinary. A solid understanding of where Caribbean history has come from and its possible future trajectories. I learned how to balance time and manage projects in a fairly labor intensive course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It is by far the most stimulating course I have taken at graduate school. Prof. Eller stimulates her students, listens, and creates a space in which students can think aloud about the trends, methods, and purpose of studying history as a practice, and of Caribbean history as a field. Professor Eller also made conscious efforts to ensure everyone in the seminar was invited to add to the conversation. I can only speak to the course's strengths. Though it was labor intensive (more so than most other grad. courses at Yale so far) I believe my writing skills and knowledge base have improved by taking the course. Prof. Eller is also incredibly helpful in suggesting additional reading in your field of interest. Working with students at Cornell was incredibly productive and I aim to reach out to fellow colleagues at Cornell to propose panels for conferences in the future.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I could not recommend this course highly enough. The level of intellectual stimulation in this course has been second to none for me. Prof. Eller forces students to think in new ways while also encouraging students to appreciate how the field has shifted.
